PERSONAE.TITLE: Dramatis Personae
PERSONAE.PERSONA: DUKE OF MILAN, Father to Silvia.
THURIO, a foolish rival to Valentine.
EGLAMOUR, Agent for Silvia in her escape.
SPEED, a clownish servant to Valentine.

PLAY.SCNDESCR: SCENE Verona; Milan; the frontiers of Mantua.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: Cease to persuade, my loving Proteus:
Home-keeping youth have ever homely wits.
Were't not affection chains thy tender days
To the sweet glances of thy honour'd love,
I rather would entreat thy company
To see the wonders of the world abroad,
Than, living dully sluggardized at home,
Wear out thy youth with shapeless idleness.
But since thou lovest, love still and thrive therein,
Even as I would when I to love begin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: Wilt thou be gone? Sweet Valentine, adieu!
Think on thy Proteus, when thou haply seest
Some rare note-worthy object in thy travel:
Wish me partaker in thy happiness
When thou dost meet good hap; and in thy danger,
If ever danger do environ thee,
Commend thy grievance to my holy prayers,
For I will be thy beadsman, Valentine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: And on a love-book pray for my success?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: Upon some book I love I'll pray for thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: That's on some shallow story of deep love:
How young Leander cross'd the Hellespont.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: That's a deep story of a deeper love:
For he was more than over shoes in love.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: 'Tis true; for you are over boots in love,
And yet you never swum the Hellespont.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: Over the boots? nay, give me not the boots.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: No, I will not, for it boots thee not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: What?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: To be in love, where scorn is bought with groans;
Coy looks with heart-sore sighs; one fading moment's mirth
With twenty watchful, weary, tedious nights:
If haply won, perhaps a hapless gain;
If lost, why then a grievous labour won;
However, but a folly bought with wit,
Or else a wit by folly vanquished.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: So, by your circumstance, you call me fool.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: So, by your circumstance, I fear you'll prove.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: 'Tis love you cavil at: I am not Love.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: Love is your master, for he masters you:
And he that is so yoked by a fool,
Methinks, should not be chronicled for wise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: Yet writers say, as in the sweetest bud
The eating canker dwells, so eating love
Inhabits in the finest wits of all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: And writers say, as the most forward bud
Is eaten by the canker ere it blow,
Even so by love the young and tender wit
Is turn'd to folly, blasting in the bud,
Losing his verdure even in the prime
And all the fair effects of future hopes.
But wherefore waste I time to counsel thee,
That art a votary to fond desire?
Once more adieu! my father at the road
Expects my coming, there to see me shipp'd.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: And thither will I bring thee, Valentine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: Sweet Proteus, no; now let us take our leave.
To Milan let me hear from thee by letters
Of thy success in love, and what news else
Betideth here in absence of thy friend;
And likewise will visit thee with mine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: All happiness bechance to thee in Milan!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: As much to you at home! and so, farewell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: He after honour hunts, I after love:
He leaves his friends to dignify them more,
I leave myself, my friends and all, for love.
Thou, Julia, thou hast metamorphosed me,
Made me neglect my studies, lose my time,
War with good counsel, set the world at nought;
Made wit with musing weak, heart sick with thought.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: Sir Proteus, save you! Saw you my master?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: But now he parted hence, to embark for Milan.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: Twenty to one then he is shipp'd already,
And I have play'd the sheep in losing him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: Indeed, a sheep doth very often stray,
An if the shepherd be a while away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: You conclude that my master is a shepherd, then,
and I a sheep?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: I do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: Why then, my horns are his horns, whether I wake or sleep.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: A silly answer and fitting well a sheep.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: This proves me still a sheep.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: True; and thy master a shepherd.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, that I can deny by a circumstance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: It shall go hard but I'll prove it by another.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: The shepherd seeks the sheep, and not the sheep the
shepherd; but I seek my master, and my master seeks
not me: therefore I am no sheep.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: The sheep for fodder follow the shepherd; the
shepherd for food follows not the sheep: thou for
wages followest thy master; thy master for wages
follows not thee: therefore thou art a sheep.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: Such another proof will make me cry 'baa.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: But, dost thou hear? gavest thou my letter to Julia?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: Ay sir: I, a lost mutton, gave your letter to her,
a laced mutton, and she, a laced mutton, gave me, a
lost mutton, nothing for my labour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: Here's too small a pasture for such store of muttons.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: If the ground be overcharged, you were best stick her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: Nay: in that you are astray, 'twere best pound you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, sir, less than a pound shall serve me for
carrying your letter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: You mistake; I mean the pound,--a pinfold.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: From a pound to a pin? fold it over and over,
'Tis threefold too little for carrying a letter to
your lover.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: But what said she?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: First nodding Ay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: Nod--Ay--why, that's noddy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: You mistook, sir; I say, she did nod: and you ask
me if she did nod; and I say, 'Ay.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: And that set together is noddy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: Now you have taken the pains to set it together,
take it for your pains.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: No, no; you shall have it for bearing the letter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: Well, I perceive I must be fain to bear with you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: Why sir, how do you bear with me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: Marry, sir, the letter, very orderly; having nothing
but the word 'noddy' for my pains.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: Beshrew me, but you have a quick wit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: And yet it cannot overtake your slow purse.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: Come come, open the matter in brief: what said she?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: Open your purse, that the money and the matter may
be both at once delivered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: Well, sir, here is for your pains. What said she?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: Truly, sir, I think you'll hardly win her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: Why, couldst thou perceive so much from her?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, I could perceive nothing at all from her; no,
not so much as a ducat for delivering your letter:
and being so hard to me that brought your mind, I
fear she'll prove as hard to you in telling your
mind. Give her no token but stones; for she's as
hard as steel.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: What said she? nothing?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: No, not so much as 'Take this for thy pains.' To
testify your bounty, I thank you, you have testerned
me; in requital whereof, henceforth carry your
letters yourself: and so, sir, I'll commend you to my master.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: Go, go, be gone, to save your ship from wreck,
Which cannot perish having thee aboard,
Being destined to a drier death on shore.
I must go send some better messenger:
I fear my Julia would not deign my lines,
Receiving them from such a worthless post.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIA
SPEECH.LINE: But say, Lucetta, now we are alone,
Wouldst thou then counsel me to fall in love?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCETTA
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, madam, so you stumble not unheedfully.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIA
SPEECH.LINE: Of all the fair resort of gentlemen
That every day with parle encounter me,
In thy opinion which is worthiest love?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCETTA
SPEECH.LINE: Please you repeat their names, I'll show my mind
According to my shallow simple skill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIA
SPEECH.LINE: What think'st thou of the fair Sir Eglamour?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCETTA
SPEECH.LINE: As of a knight well-spoken, neat and fine;
But, were I you, he never should be mine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIA
SPEECH.LINE: What think'st thou of the rich Mercatio?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCETTA
SPEECH.LINE: Well of his wealth; but of himself, so so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIA
SPEECH.LINE: What think'st thou of the gentle Proteus?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCETTA
SPEECH.LINE: Lord, Lord! to see what folly reigns in us!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIA
SPEECH.LINE: How now! what means this passion at his name?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCETTA
SPEECH.LINE: Pardon, dear madam: 'tis a passing shame
That I, unworthy body as I am,
Should censure thus on lovely gentlemen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIA
SPEECH.LINE: Why not on Proteus, as of all the rest?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCETTA
SPEECH.LINE: Then thus: of many good I think him best.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIA
SPEECH.LINE: Your reason?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCETTA
SPEECH.LINE: I have no other, but a woman's reason;
I think him so because I think him so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIA
SPEECH.LINE: And wouldst thou have me cast my love on him?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCETTA
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, if you thought your love not cast away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIA
SPEECH.LINE: Why he, of all the rest, hath never moved me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCETTA
SPEECH.LINE: Yet he, of all the rest, I think, best loves ye.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIA
SPEECH.LINE: His little speaking shows his love but small.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCETTA
SPEECH.LINE: Fire that's closest kept burns most of all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIA
SPEECH.LINE: They do not love that do not show their love.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCETTA
SPEECH.LINE: O, they love least that let men know their love.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIA
SPEECH.LINE: I would I knew his mind.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCETTA
SPEECH.LINE: Peruse this paper, madam.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIA
SPEECH.LINE: 'To Julia.' Say, from whom?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCETTA
SPEECH.LINE: That the contents will show.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIA
SPEECH.LINE: Say, say, who gave it thee?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCETTA
SPEECH.LINE: Valentine's page; and sent, I think, from Proteus.
He would have given it you; but I, being in the way,
Did in your name receive it: pardon the
fault I pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIA
SPEECH.LINE: Now, by my modesty, a goodly broker!
Dare you presume to harbour wanton lines?
To whisper and conspire against my youth?
Now, trust me, 'tis an office of great worth
And you an officer fit for the place.
Or else return no more into my sight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCETTA
SPEECH.LINE: To plead for love deserves more fee than hate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIA
SPEECH.LINE: Will ye be gone?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCETTA
SPEECH.LINE: That you may ruminate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIA
SPEECH.LINE: And yet I would I had o'erlooked the letter:
It were a shame to call her back again
And pray her to a fault for which I chid her.
What a fool is she, that knows I am a maid,
And would not force the letter to my view!
Since maids, in modesty, say 'no' to that
Which they would have the profferer construe 'ay.'
Fie, fie, how wayward is this foolish love
That, like a testy babe, will scratch the nurse
And presently all humbled kiss the rod!
How churlishly I chid Lucetta hence,
When willingly I would have had her here!
How angerly I taught my brow to frown,
When inward joy enforced my heart to smile!
My penance is to call Lucetta back
And ask remission for my folly past.
What ho! Lucetta!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCETTA
SPEECH.LINE: What would your ladyship?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIA
SPEECH.LINE: Is't near dinner-time?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCETTA
SPEECH.LINE: I would it were,
That you might kill your stomach on your meat
And not upon your maid.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIA
SPEECH.LINE: What is't that you took up so gingerly?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCETTA
SPEECH.LINE: Nothing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIA
SPEECH.LINE: Why didst thou stoop, then?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCETTA
SPEECH.LINE: To take a paper up that I let fall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIA
SPEECH.LINE: And is that paper nothing?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCETTA
SPEECH.LINE: Nothing concerning me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIA
SPEECH.LINE: Then let it lie for those that it concerns.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCETTA
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, it will not lie where it concerns
Unless it have a false interpeter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIA
SPEECH.LINE: Some love of yours hath writ to you in rhyme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCETTA
SPEECH.LINE: That I might sing it, madam, to a tune.
Give me a note: your ladyship can set.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIA
SPEECH.LINE: As little by such toys as may be possible.
Best sing it to the tune of 'Light o' love.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCETTA
SPEECH.LINE: It is too heavy for so light a tune.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIA
SPEECH.LINE: Heavy! belike it hath some burden then?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCETTA
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, and melodious were it, would you sing it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIA
SPEECH.LINE: And why not you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCETTA
SPEECH.LINE: I cannot reach so high.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIA
SPEECH.LINE: Let's see your song. How now, minion!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCETTA
SPEECH.LINE: Keep tune there still, so you will sing it out:
And yet methinks I do not like this tune.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIA
SPEECH.LINE: You do not?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCETTA
SPEECH.LINE: No, madam; it is too sharp.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIA
SPEECH.LINE: You, minion, are too saucy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCETTA
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, now you are too flat
And mar the concord with too harsh a descant:
There wanteth but a mean to fill your song.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIA
SPEECH.LINE: The mean is drown'd with your unruly bass.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCETTA
SPEECH.LINE: Indeed, I bid the base for Proteus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIA
SPEECH.LINE: This babble shall not henceforth trouble me.
Here is a coil with protestation!
Go get you gone, and let the papers lie:
You would be fingering them, to anger me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCETTA
SPEECH.LINE: She makes it strange; but she would be best pleased
To be so anger'd with another letter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIA
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, would I were so anger'd with the same!
O hateful hands, to tear such loving words!
Injurious wasps, to feed on such sweet honey
And kill the bees that yield it with your stings!
I'll kiss each several paper for amends.
Look, here is writ 'kind Julia.' Unkind Julia!
As in revenge of thy ingratitude,
I throw thy name against the bruising stones,
Trampling contemptuously on thy disdain.
And here is writ 'love-wounded Proteus.'
Poor wounded name! my bosom as a bed
Shall lodge thee till thy wound be thoroughly heal'd;
And thus I search it with a sovereign kiss.
But twice or thrice was 'Proteus' written down.
Be calm, good wind, blow not a word away
Till I have found each letter in the letter,
Except mine own name: that some whirlwind bear
Unto a ragged fearful-hanging rock
And throw it thence into the raging sea!
Lo, here in one line is his name twice writ,
'Poor forlorn Proteus, passionate Proteus,
To the sweet Julia:' that I'll tear away.
And yet I will not, sith so prettily
He couples it to his complaining names.
Thus will I fold them one on another:
Now kiss, embrace, contend, do what you will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCETTA
SPEECH.LINE: Madam,
Dinner is ready, and your father stays.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIA
SPEECH.LINE: Well, let us go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCETTA
SPEECH.LINE: What, shall these papers lie like tell-tales here?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIA
SPEECH.LINE: If you respect them, best to take them up.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCETTA
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, I was taken up for laying them down:
Yet here they shall not lie, for catching cold.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIA
SPEECH.LINE: I see you have a month's mind to them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCETTA
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, madam, you may say what sights you see;
I see things too, although you judge I wink.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIA
SPEECH.LINE: Come, come; will't please you go?

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE III. The same. ANTONIO's house.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTONIO
SPEECH.LINE: Tell me, Panthino, what sad talk was that
Wherewith my brother held you in the cloister?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PANTHINO
SPEECH.LINE: 'Twas of his nephew Proteus, your son.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTONIO
SPEECH.LINE: Why, what of him?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PANTHINO
SPEECH.LINE: He wonder'd that your lordship
Would suffer him to spend his youth at home,
While other men, of slender reputation,
Put forth their sons to seek preferment out:
Some to the wars, to try their fortune there;
Some to discover islands far away;
Some to the studious universities.
For any or for all these exercises,
He said that Proteus your son was meet,
And did request me to importune you
To let him spend his time no more at home,
Which would be great impeachment to his age,
In having known no travel in his youth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTONIO
SPEECH.LINE: Nor need'st thou much importune me to that
Whereon this month I have been hammering.
I have consider'd well his loss of time
And how he cannot be a perfect man,
Not being tried and tutor'd in the world:
Experience is by industry achieved
And perfected by the swift course of time.
Then tell me, whither were I best to send him?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PANTHINO
SPEECH.LINE: I think your lordship is not ignorant
How his companion, youthful Valentine,
Attends the emperor in his royal court.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTONIO
SPEECH.LINE: I know it well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PANTHINO
SPEECH.LINE: 'Twere good, I think, your lordship sent him thither:
There shall he practise tilts and tournaments,
Hear sweet discourse, converse with noblemen.
And be in eye of every exercise
Worthy his youth and nobleness of birth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTONIO
SPEECH.LINE: I like thy counsel; well hast thou advised:
And that thou mayst perceive how well I like it,
The execution of it shall make known.
Even with the speediest expedition
I will dispatch him to the emperor's court.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PANTHINO
SPEECH.LINE: To-morrow, may it please you, Don Alphonso,
With other gentlemen of good esteem,
Are journeying to salute the emperor
And to commend their service to his will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTONIO
SPEECH.LINE: Good company; with them shall Proteus go:
And, in good time! now will we break with him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: Sweet love! sweet lines! sweet life!
Here is her hand, the agent of her heart;
Here is her oath for love, her honour's pawn.
O, that our fathers would applaud our loves,
To seal our happiness with their consents!
O heavenly Julia!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTONIO
SPEECH.LINE: How now! what letter are you reading there?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: May't please your lordship, 'tis a word or two
Of commendations sent from Valentine,
Deliver'd by a friend that came from him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTONIO
SPEECH.LINE: Lend me the letter; let me see what news.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: There is no news, my lord, but that he writes
How happily he lives, how well beloved
And daily graced by the emperor;
Wishing me with him, partner of his fortune.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTONIO
SPEECH.LINE: And how stand you affected to his wish?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: As one relying on your lordship's will
And not depending on his friendly wish.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTONIO
SPEECH.LINE: My will is something sorted with his wish.
Muse not that I thus suddenly proceed;
For what I will, I will, and there an end.
I am resolved that thou shalt spend some time
With Valentinus in the emperor's court:
What maintenance he from his friends receives,
Like exhibition thou shalt have from me.
To-morrow be in readiness to go:
Excuse it not, for I am peremptory.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: My lord, I cannot be so soon provided:
Please you, deliberate a day or two.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTONIO
SPEECH.LINE: Look, what thou want'st shall be sent after thee:
No more of stay! to-morrow thou must go.
Come on, Panthino: you shall be employ'd
To hasten on his expedition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: Thus have I shunn'd the fire for fear of burning,
And drench'd me in the sea, where I am drown'd.
I fear'd to show my father Julia's letter,
Lest he should take exceptions to my love;
And with the vantage of mine own excuse
Hath he excepted most against my love.
O, how this spring of love resembleth
The uncertain glory of an April day,
Which now shows all the beauty of the sun,
And by and by a cloud takes all away!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PANTHINO
SPEECH.LINE: Sir Proteus, your father calls for you:
He is in haste; therefore, I pray you to go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: Why, this it is: my heart accords thereto,
And yet a thousand times it answers 'no.'

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, your glove.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: Not mine; my gloves are on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: Why, then, this may be yours, for this is but one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: Ha! let me see: ay, give it me, it's mine:
Sweet ornament that decks a thing divine!
Ah, Silvia, Silvia!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: Madam Silvia! Madam Silvia!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: How now, sirrah?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: She is not within hearing, sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: Why, sir, who bade you call her?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: Your worship, sir; or else I mistook.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: Well, you'll still be too forward.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: And yet I was last chidden for being too slow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: Go to, sir: tell me, do you know Madam Silvia?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: She that your worship loves?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: Why, how know you that I am in love?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: Marry, by these special marks: first, you have
learned, like Sir Proteus, to wreathe your arms,
like a malecontent; to relish a love-song, like a
robin-redbreast; to walk alone, like one that had
the pestilence; to sigh, like a school-boy that had
lost his A B C; to weep, like a young wench that had
buried her grandam; to fast, like one that takes
diet; to watch like one that fears robbing; to
speak puling, like a beggar at Hallowmas. You were
wont, when you laughed, to crow like a cock; when you
walked, to walk like one of the lions; when you
fasted, it was presently after dinner; when you
looked sadly, it was for want of money: and now you
are metamorphosed with a mistress, that, when I look
on you, I can hardly think you my master.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: Are all these things perceived in me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: They are all perceived without ye.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: Without me? they cannot.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: Without you? nay, that's certain, for, without you
were so simple, none else would: but you are so
without these follies, that these follies are within
you and shine through you like the water in an
urinal, that not an eye that sees you but is a
physician to comment on your malady.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: But tell me, dost thou know my lady Silvia?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: She that you gaze on so as she sits at supper?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: Hast thou observed that? even she, I mean.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: Why, sir, I know her not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: Dost thou know her by my gazing on her, and yet
knowest her not?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: Is she not hard-favoured, sir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: Not so fair, boy, as well-favoured.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, I know that well enough.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: What dost thou know?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: That she is not so fair as, of you, well-favoured.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: I mean that her beauty is exquisite, but her favour infinite.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: That's because the one is painted and the other out
of all count.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: How painted? and how out of count?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: Marry, sir, so painted, to make her fair, that no
man counts of her beauty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: How esteemest thou me? I account of her beauty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: You never saw her since she was deformed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: How long hath she been deformed?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: Ever since you loved her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: I have loved her ever since I saw her; and still I
see her beautiful.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: If you love her, you cannot see her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: Why?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: Because Love is blind. O, that you had mine eyes;
or your own eyes had the lights they were wont to
have when you chid at Sir Proteus for going
ungartered!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: What should I see then?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: Your own present folly and her passing deformity:
for he, being in love, could not see to garter his
hose, and you, being in love, cannot see to put on your hose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: Belike, boy, then, you are in love; for last
morning you could not see to wipe my shoes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: True, sir; I was in love with my bed: I thank you,
you swinged me for my love, which makes me the
bolder to chide you for yours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: In conclusion, I stand affected to her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: I would you were set, so your affection would cease.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: Last night she enjoined me to write some lines to
one she loves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: And have you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: I have.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: Are they not lamely writ?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: No, boy, but as well as I can do them. Peace!
here she comes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: Aside O excellent motion! O exceeding puppet!
Now will he interpret to her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: Madam and mistress, a thousand good-morrows.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: Aside O, give ye good even! here's a million of manners.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SILVIA
SPEECH.LINE: Sir Valentine and servant, to you two thousand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: Aside He should give her interest and she gives it him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: As you enjoin'd me, I have writ your letter
Unto the secret nameless friend of yours;
Which I was much unwilling to proceed in
But for my duty to your ladyship.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SILVIA
SPEECH.LINE: I thank you gentle servant: 'tis very clerkly done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: Now trust me, madam, it came hardly off;
For being ignorant to whom it goes
I writ at random, very doubtfully.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SILVIA
SPEECH.LINE: Perchance you think too much of so much pains?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: No, madam; so it stead you, I will write
Please you command, a thousand times as much; And yet--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SILVIA
SPEECH.LINE: A pretty period! Well, I guess the sequel;
And yet I will not name it; and yet I care not;
And yet take this again; and yet I thank you,
Meaning henceforth to trouble you no more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: Aside And yet you will; and yet another 'yet.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: What means your ladyship? do you not like it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SILVIA
SPEECH.LINE: Yes, yes; the lines are very quaintly writ;
But since unwillingly, take them again.
Nay, take them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, they are for you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SILVIA
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, ay: you writ them, sir, at my request;
But I will none of them; they are for you;
I would have had them writ more movingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: Please you, I'll write your ladyship another.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SILVIA
SPEECH.LINE: And when it's writ, for my sake read it over,
And if it please you, so; if not, why, so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: If it please me, madam, what then?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SILVIA
SPEECH.LINE: Why, if it please you, take it for your labour:
And so, good morrow, servant.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: O jest unseen, inscrutable, invisible,
As a nose on a man's face, or a weathercock on a steeple!
My master sues to her, and she hath
taught her suitor,
He being her pupil, to become her tutor.
O excellent device! was there ever heard a better,
That my master, being scribe, to himself should write
the letter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: How now, sir? what are you reasoning with yourself?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, I was rhyming: 'tis you that have the reason.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: To do what?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: To be a spokesman for Madam Silvia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: To whom?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: To yourself: why, she wooes you by a figure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: What figure?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: By a letter, I should say.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: Why, she hath not writ to me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: What need she, when she hath made you write to
yourself? Why, do you not perceive the jest?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: No, believe me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: No believing you, indeed, sir. But did you perceive
her earnest?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: She gave me none, except an angry word.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: Why, she hath given you a letter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: That's the letter I writ to her friend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: And that letter hath she delivered, and there an end.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: I would it were no worse.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: I'll warrant you, 'tis as well:
For often have you writ to her, and she, in modesty,
Or else for want of idle time, could not again reply;
Or fearing else some messenger that might her mind discover,
Herself hath taught her love himself to write unto her lover.
All this I speak in print, for in print I found it.
Why muse you, sir? 'tis dinner-time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: I have dined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, but hearken, sir; though the chameleon Love can
feed on the air, I am one that am nourished by my
victuals, and would fain have meat. O, be not like
your mistress; be moved, be moved.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE II. Verona. JULIA'S house.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: Have patience, gentle Julia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIA
SPEECH.LINE: I must, where is no remedy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: When possibly I can, I will return.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIA
SPEECH.LINE: If you turn not, you will return the sooner.
Keep this remembrance for thy Julia's sake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: Why then, we'll make exchange; here, take you this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIA
SPEECH.LINE: And seal the bargain with a holy kiss.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: Here is my hand for my true constancy;
And when that hour o'erslips me in the day
Wherein I sigh not, Julia, for thy sake,
The next ensuing hour some foul mischance
Torment me for my love's forgetfulness!
My father stays my coming; answer not;
The tide is now: nay, not thy tide of tears;
That tide will stay me longer than I should.
Julia, farewell!
What, gone without a word?
Ay, so true love should do: it cannot speak;
For truth hath better deeds than words to grace it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PANTHINO
SPEECH.LINE: Sir Proteus, you are stay'd for.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: Go; I come, I come.
Alas! this parting strikes poor lovers dumb.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE III. The same. A street.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAUNCE
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, 'twill be this hour ere I have done weeping;
all the kind of the Launces have this very fault. I
have received my proportion, like the prodigious
son, and am going with Sir Proteus to the Imperial's
court. I think Crab, my dog, be the sourest-natured
dog that lives: my mother weeping, my father
wailing, my sister crying, our maid howling, our cat
wringing her hands, and all our house in a great
perplexity, yet did not this cruel-hearted cur shed
one tear: he is a stone, a very pebble stone, and
has no more pity in him than a dog: a Jew would have
wept to have seen our parting; why, my grandam,
having no eyes, look you, wept herself blind at my
parting. Nay, I'll show you the manner of it. This
shoe is my father: no, this left shoe is my father:
no, no, this left shoe is my mother: nay, that
cannot be so neither: yes, it is so, it is so, it
hath the worser sole. This shoe, with the hole in
it, is my mother, and this my father; a vengeance
on't! there 'tis: now, sit, this staff is my
sister, for, look you, she is as white as a lily and
as small as a wand: this hat is Nan, our maid: I
am the dog: no, the dog is himself, and I am the
dog--Oh! the dog is me, and I am myself; ay, so,
so. Now come I to my father; Father, your blessing:
now should not the shoe speak a word for weeping:
now should I kiss my father; well, he weeps on. Now
come I to my mother: O, that she could speak now
like a wood woman! Well, I kiss her; why, there
'tis; here's my mother's breath up and down. Now
come I to my sister; mark the moan she makes. Now
the dog all this while sheds not a tear nor speaks a
word; but see how I lay the dust with my tears.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PANTHINO
SPEECH.LINE: Launce, away, away, aboard! thy master is shipped
and thou art to post after with oars. What's the
matter? why weepest thou, man? Away, ass! You'll
lose the tide, if you tarry any longer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAUNCE
SPEECH.LINE: It is no matter if the tied were lost; for it is the
unkindest tied that ever any man tied.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PANTHINO
SPEECH.LINE: What's the unkindest tide?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAUNCE
SPEECH.LINE: Why, he that's tied here, Crab, my dog.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PANTHINO
SPEECH.LINE: Tut, man, I mean thou'lt lose the flood, and, in
losing the flood, lose thy voyage, and, in losing
thy voyage, lose thy master, and, in losing thy
master, lose thy service, and, in losing thy
service,--Why dost thou stop my mouth?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAUNCE
SPEECH.LINE: For fear thou shouldst lose thy tongue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PANTHINO
SPEECH.LINE: Where should I lose my tongue?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAUNCE
SPEECH.LINE: In thy tale.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PANTHINO
SPEECH.LINE: In thy tail!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAUNCE
SPEECH.LINE: Lose the tide, and the voyage, and the master, and
the service, and the tied! Why, man, if the river
were dry, I am able to fill it with my tears; if the
wind were down, I could drive the boat with my sighs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PANTHINO
SPEECH.LINE: Come, come away, man; I was sent to call thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAUNCE
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, call me what thou darest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PANTHINO
SPEECH.LINE: Wilt thou go?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAUNCE
SPEECH.LINE: Well, I will go.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter SILVIA, VALENTINE, THURIO, and SPEED

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SILVIA
SPEECH.LINE: Servant!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: Mistress?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: Master, Sir Thurio frowns on you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, boy, it's for love.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: Not of you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: Of my mistress, then.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: 'Twere good you knocked him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SILVIA
SPEECH.LINE: Servant, you are sad.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: Indeed, madam, I seem so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THURIO
SPEECH.LINE: Seem you that you are not?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: Haply I do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THURIO
SPEECH.LINE: So do counterfeits.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: So do you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THURIO
SPEECH.LINE: What seem I that I am not?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: Wise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THURIO
SPEECH.LINE: What instance of the contrary?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: Your folly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THURIO
SPEECH.LINE: And how quote you my folly?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: I quote it in your jerkin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THURIO
SPEECH.LINE: My jerkin is a doublet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: Well, then, I'll double your folly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THURIO
SPEECH.LINE: How?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SILVIA
SPEECH.LINE: What, angry, Sir Thurio! do you change colour?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: Give him leave, madam; he is a kind of chameleon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THURIO
SPEECH.LINE: That hath more mind to feed on your blood than live
in your air.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: You have said, sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THURIO
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, sir, and done too, for this time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: I know it well, sir; you always end ere you begin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SILVIA
SPEECH.LINE: A fine volley of words, gentlemen, and quickly shot off.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: 'Tis indeed, madam; we thank the giver.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SILVIA
SPEECH.LINE: Who is that, servant?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: Yourself, sweet lady; for you gave the fire. Sir
Thurio borrows his wit from your ladyship's looks,
and spends what he borrows kindly in your company.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THURIO
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, if you spend word for word with me, I shall
make your wit bankrupt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: I know it well, sir; you have an exchequer of words,
and, I think, no other treasure to give your
followers, for it appears by their bare liveries,
that they live by your bare words.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SILVIA
SPEECH.LINE: No more, gentlemen, no more:--here comes my father.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE
SPEECH.LINE: Now, daughter Silvia, you are hard beset.
Sir Valentine, your father's in good health:
What say you to a letter from your friends
Of much good news?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: My lord, I will be thankful.
To any happy messenger from thence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE
SPEECH.LINE: Know ye Don Antonio, your countryman?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, my good lord, I know the gentleman
To be of worth and worthy estimation
And not without desert so well reputed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE
SPEECH.LINE: Hath he not a son?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, my good lord; a son that well deserves
The honour and regard of such a father.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE
SPEECH.LINE: You know him well?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: I know him as myself; for from our infancy
We have conversed and spent our hours together:
And though myself have been an idle truant,
Omitting the sweet benefit of time
To clothe mine age with angel-like perfection,
Yet hath Sir Proteus, for that's his name,
Made use and fair advantage of his days;
His years but young, but his experience old;
His head unmellow'd, but his judgment ripe;
And, in a word, for far behind his worth
Comes all the praises that I now bestow,
He is complete in feature and in mind
With all good grace to grace a gentleman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE
SPEECH.LINE: Beshrew me, sir, but if he make this good,
He is as worthy for an empress' love
As meet to be an emperor's counsellor.
Well, sir, this gentleman is come to me,
With commendation from great potentates;
And here he means to spend his time awhile:
I think 'tis no unwelcome news to you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: Should I have wish'd a thing, it had been he.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE
SPEECH.LINE: Welcome him then according to his worth.
Silvia, I speak to you, and you, Sir Thurio;
For Valentine, I need not cite him to it:
I will send him hither to you presently.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: This is the gentleman I told your ladyship
Had come along with me, but that his mistress
Did hold his eyes lock'd in her crystal looks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SILVIA
SPEECH.LINE: Belike that now she hath enfranchised them
Upon some other pawn for fealty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, sure, I think she holds them prisoners still.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SILVIA
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, then he should be blind; and, being blind
How could he see his way to seek out you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: Why, lady, Love hath twenty pair of eyes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THURIO
SPEECH.LINE: They say that Love hath not an eye at all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: To see such lovers, Thurio, as yourself:
Upon a homely object Love can wink.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SILVIA
SPEECH.LINE: Have done, have done; here comes the gentleman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: Welcome, dear Proteus! Mistress, I beseech you,
Confirm his welcome with some special favour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SILVIA
SPEECH.LINE: His worth is warrant for his welcome hither,
If this be he you oft have wish'd to hear from.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: Mistress, it is: sweet lady, entertain him
To be my fellow-servant to your ladyship.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SILVIA
SPEECH.LINE: Too low a mistress for so high a servant.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: Not so, sweet lady: but too mean a servant
To have a look of such a worthy mistress.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: Leave off discourse of disability:
Sweet lady, entertain him for your servant.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: My duty will I boast of; nothing else.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SILVIA
SPEECH.LINE: And duty never yet did want his meed:
Servant, you are welcome to a worthless mistress.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: I'll die on him that says so but yourself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SILVIA
SPEECH.LINE: That you are welcome?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: That you are worthless.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THURIO
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, my lord your father would speak with you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SILVIA
SPEECH.LINE: I wait upon his pleasure. Come, Sir Thurio,
Go with me. Once more, new servant, welcome:
I'll leave you to confer of home affairs;
When you have done, we look to hear from you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: We'll both attend upon your ladyship.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: Now, tell me, how do all from whence you came?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: Your friends are well and have them much commended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: And how do yours?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: I left them all in health.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: How does your lady? and how thrives your love?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: My tales of love were wont to weary you;
I know you joy not in a love discourse.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, Proteus, but that life is alter'd now:
I have done penance for contemning Love,
Whose high imperious thoughts have punish'd me
With bitter fasts, with penitential groans,
With nightly tears and daily heart-sore sighs;
For in revenge of my contempt of love,
Love hath chased sleep from my enthralled eyes
And made them watchers of mine own heart's sorrow.
O gentle Proteus, Love's a mighty lord,
And hath so humbled me, as, I confess,
There is no woe to his correction,
Nor to his service no such joy on earth.
Now no discourse, except it be of love;
Now can I break my fast, dine, sup and sleep,
Upon the very naked name of love.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: Enough; I read your fortune in your eye.
Was this the idol that you worship so?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: Even she; and is she not a heavenly saint?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: No; but she is an earthly paragon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: Call her divine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: I will not flatter her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: O, flatter me; for love delights in praises.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: When I was sick, you gave me bitter pills,
And I must minister the like to you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: Then speak the truth by her; if not divine,
Yet let her be a principality,
Sovereign to all the creatures on the earth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: Except my mistress.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: Sweet, except not any;
Except thou wilt except against my love.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: Have I not reason to prefer mine own?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: And I will help thee to prefer her too:
She shall be dignified with this high honour--
To bear my lady's train, lest the base earth
Should from her vesture chance to steal a kiss
And, of so great a favour growing proud,
Disdain to root the summer-swelling flower
And make rough winter everlastingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: Why, Valentine, what braggardism is this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: Pardon me, Proteus: all I can is nothing
To her whose worth makes other worthies nothing;
She is alone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: Then let her alone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: Not for the world: why, man, she is mine own,
And I as rich in having such a jewel
As twenty seas, if all their sand were pearl,
The water nectar and the rocks pure gold.
Forgive me that I do not dream on thee,
Because thou see'st me dote upon my love.
My foolish rival, that her father likes
Only for his possessions are so huge,
Is gone with her along, and I must after,
For love, thou know'st, is full of jealousy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: But she loves you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, and we are betroth'd: nay, more, our,
marriage-hour,
With all the cunning manner of our flight,
Determined of; how I must climb her window,
The ladder made of cords, and all the means
Plotted and 'greed on for my happiness.
Good Proteus, go with me to my chamber,
In these affairs to aid me with thy counsel.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: Go on before; I shall inquire you forth:
I must unto the road, to disembark
Some necessaries that I needs must use,
And then I'll presently attend you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: Will you make haste?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: I will.
Even as one heat another heat expels,
Or as one nail by strength drives out another,
So the remembrance of my former love
Is by a newer object quite forgotten.
Is it mine, or Valentine's praise,
Her true perfection, or my false transgression,
That makes me reasonless to reason thus?
She is fair; and so is Julia that I love--
That I did love, for now my love is thaw'd;
Which, like a waxen image, 'gainst a fire,
Bears no impression of the thing it was.
Methinks my zeal to Valentine is cold,
And that I love him not as I was wont.
O, but I love his lady too too much,
And that's the reason I love him so little.
How shall I dote on her with more advice,
That thus without advice begin to love her!
'Tis but her picture I have yet beheld,
And that hath dazzled my reason's light;
But when I look on her perfections,
There is no reason but I shall be blind.
If I can cheque my erring love, I will;
If not, to compass her I'll use my skill.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE V. The same. A street.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: Launce! by mine honesty, welcome to Milan!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAUNCE
SPEECH.LINE: Forswear not thyself, sweet youth, for I am not
welcome. I reckon this always, that a man is never
undone till he be hanged, nor never welcome to a
place till some certain shot be paid and the hostess
say 'Welcome!'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: Come on, you madcap, I'll to the alehouse with you
presently; where, for one shot of five pence, thou
shalt have five thousand welcomes. But, sirrah, how
did thy master part with Madam Julia?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAUNCE
SPEECH.LINE: Marry, after they closed in earnest, they parted very
fairly in jest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: But shall she marry him?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAUNCE
SPEECH.LINE: No.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: How then? shall he marry her?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAUNCE
SPEECH.LINE: No, neither.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: What, are they broken?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAUNCE
SPEECH.LINE: No, they are both as whole as a fish.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: Why, then, how stands the matter with them?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAUNCE
SPEECH.LINE: Marry, thus: when it stands well with him, it
stands well with her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: What an ass art thou! I understand thee not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAUNCE
SPEECH.LINE: What a block art thou, that thou canst not! My
staff understands me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: What thou sayest?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAUNCE
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, and what I do too: look thee, I'll but lean,
and my staff understands me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: It stands under thee, indeed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAUNCE
SPEECH.LINE: Why, stand-under and under-stand is all one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: But tell me true, will't be a match?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAUNCE
SPEECH.LINE: Ask my dog: if he say ay, it will! if he say no,
it will; if he shake his tail and say nothing, it will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: The conclusion is then that it will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAUNCE
SPEECH.LINE: Thou shalt never get such a secret from me but by a parable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: 'Tis well that I get it so. But, Launce, how sayest
thou, that my master is become a notable lover?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAUNCE
SPEECH.LINE: I never knew him otherwise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: Than how?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAUNCE
SPEECH.LINE: A notable lubber, as thou reportest him to be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: Why, thou whoreson ass, thou mistakest me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAUNCE
SPEECH.LINE: Why, fool, I meant not thee; I meant thy master.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: I tell thee, my master is become a hot lover.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAUNCE
SPEECH.LINE: Why, I tell thee, I care not though he burn himself
in love. If thou wilt, go with me to the alehouse;
if not, thou art an Hebrew, a Jew, and not worth the
name of a Christian.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: Why?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAUNCE
SPEECH.LINE: Because thou hast not so much charity in thee as to
go to the ale with a Christian. Wilt thou go?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: At thy service.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE VI. The same. The DUKE'S palace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: To leave my Julia, shall I be forsworn;
To love fair Silvia, shall I be forsworn;
To wrong my friend, I shall be much forsworn;
And even that power which gave me first my oath
Provokes me to this threefold perjury;
Love bade me swear and Love bids me forswear.
O sweet-suggesting Love, if thou hast sinned,
Teach me, thy tempted subject, to excuse it!
At first I did adore a twinkling star,
But now I worship a celestial sun.
Unheedful vows may heedfully be broken,
And he wants wit that wants resolved will
To learn his wit to exchange the bad for better.
Fie, fie, unreverend tongue! to call her bad,
Whose sovereignty so oft thou hast preferr'd
With twenty thousand soul-confirming oaths.
I cannot leave to love, and yet I do;
But there I leave to love where I should love.
Julia I lose and Valentine I lose:
If I keep them, I needs must lose myself;
If I lose them, thus find I by their loss
For Valentine myself, for Julia Silvia.
I to myself am dearer than a friend,
For love is still most precious in itself;
And Silvia--witness Heaven, that made her fair!--
Shows Julia but a swarthy Ethiope.
I will forget that Julia is alive,
Remembering that my love to her is dead;
And Valentine I'll hold an enemy,
Aiming at Silvia as a sweeter friend.
I cannot now prove constant to myself,
Without some treachery used to Valentine.
This night he meaneth with a corded ladder
To climb celestial Silvia's chamber-window,
Myself in counsel, his competitor.
Now presently I'll give her father notice
Of their disguising and pretended flight;
Who, all enraged, will banish Valentine;
For Thurio, he intends, shall wed his daughter;
But, Valentine being gone, I'll quickly cross
By some sly trick blunt Thurio's dull proceeding.
Love, lend me wings to make my purpose swift,
As thou hast lent me wit to plot this drift!

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE VII. Verona. JULIA'S house.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIA
SPEECH.LINE: Counsel, Lucetta; gentle girl, assist me;
And even in kind love I do conjure thee,
Who art the table wherein all my thoughts
Are visibly character'd and engraved,
To lesson me and tell me some good mean
How, with my honour, I may undertake
A journey to my loving Proteus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCETTA
SPEECH.LINE: Alas, the way is wearisome and long!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIA
SPEECH.LINE: A true-devoted pilgrim is not weary
To measure kingdoms with his feeble steps;
Much less shall she that hath Love's wings to fly,
And when the flight is made to one so dear,
Of such divine perfection, as Sir Proteus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCETTA
SPEECH.LINE: Better forbear till Proteus make return.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIA
SPEECH.LINE: O, know'st thou not his looks are my soul's food?
Pity the dearth that I have pined in,
By longing for that food so long a time.
Didst thou but know the inly touch of love,
Thou wouldst as soon go kindle fire with snow
As seek to quench the fire of love with words.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCETTA
SPEECH.LINE: I do not seek to quench your love's hot fire,
But qualify the fire's extreme rage,
Lest it should burn above the bounds of reason.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIA
SPEECH.LINE: The more thou damm'st it up, the more it burns.
The current that with gentle murmur glides,
Thou know'st, being stopp'd, impatiently doth rage;
But when his fair course is not hindered,
He makes sweet music with the enamell'ed stones,
Giving a gentle kiss to every sedge
He overtaketh in his pilgrimage,
And so by many winding nooks he strays
With willing sport to the wild ocean.
Then let me go and hinder not my course
I'll be as patient as a gentle stream
And make a pastime of each weary step,
Till the last step have brought me to my love;
And there I'll rest, as after much turmoil
A blessed soul doth in Elysium.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCETTA
SPEECH.LINE: But in what habit will you go along?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIA
SPEECH.LINE: Not like a woman; for I would prevent
The loose encounters of lascivious men:
Gentle Lucetta, fit me with such weeds
As may beseem some well-reputed page.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCETTA
SPEECH.LINE: Why, then, your ladyship must cut your hair.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIA
SPEECH.LINE: No, girl, I'll knit it up in silken strings
With twenty odd-conceited true-love knots.
To be fantastic may become a youth
Of greater time than I shall show to be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCETTA
SPEECH.LINE: What fashion, madam shall I make your breeches?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIA
SPEECH.LINE: That fits as well as 'Tell me, good my lord,
What compass will you wear your farthingale?'
Why even what fashion thou best likest, Lucetta.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCETTA
SPEECH.LINE: You must needs have them with a codpiece, madam.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIA
SPEECH.LINE: Out, out, Lucetta! that would be ill-favour'd.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCETTA
SPEECH.LINE: A round hose, madam, now's not worth a pin,
Unless you have a codpiece to stick pins on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIA
SPEECH.LINE: Lucetta, as thou lovest me, let me have
What thou thinkest meet and is most mannerly.
But tell me, wench, how will the world repute me
For undertaking so unstaid a journey?
I fear me, it will make me scandalized.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCETTA
SPEECH.LINE: If you think so, then stay at home and go not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIA
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, that I will not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCETTA
SPEECH.LINE: Then never dream on infamy, but go.
If Proteus like your journey when you come,
No matter who's displeased when you are gone:
I fear me, he will scarce be pleased withal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIA
SPEECH.LINE: That is the least, Lucetta, of my fear:
A thousand oaths, an ocean of his tears
And instances of infinite of love
Warrant me welcome to my Proteus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCETTA
SPEECH.LINE: All these are servants to deceitful men.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIA
SPEECH.LINE: Base men, that use them to so base effect!
But truer stars did govern Proteus' birth
His words are bonds, his oaths are oracles,
His love sincere, his thoughts immaculate,
His tears pure messengers sent from his heart,
His heart as far from fraud as heaven from earth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCETTA
SPEECH.LINE: Pray heaven he prove so, when you come to him!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIA
SPEECH.LINE: Now, as thou lovest me, do him not that wrong
To bear a hard opinion of his truth:
Only deserve my love by loving him;
And presently go with me to my chamber,
To take a note of what I stand in need of,
To furnish me upon my longing journey.
All that is mine I leave at thy dispose,
My goods, my lands, my reputation;
Only, in lieu thereof, dispatch me hence.
Come, answer not, but to it presently!
I am impatient of my tarriance.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE
SPEECH.LINE: Sir Thurio, give us leave, I pray, awhile;
We have some secrets to confer about.
Now, tell me, Proteus, what's your will with me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: My gracious lord, that which I would discover
The law of friendship bids me to conceal;
But when I call to mind your gracious favours
Done to me, undeserving as I am,
My duty pricks me on to utter that
Which else no worldly good should draw from me.
Know, worthy prince, Sir Valentine, my friend,
This night intends to steal away your daughter:
Myself am one made privy to the plot.
I know you have determined to bestow her
On Thurio, whom your gentle daughter hates;
And should she thus be stol'n away from you,
It would be much vexation to your age.
Thus, for my duty's sake, I rather chose
To cross my friend in his intended drift
Than, by concealing it, heap on your head
A pack of sorrows which would press you down,
Being unprevented, to your timeless grave.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE
SPEECH.LINE: Proteus, I thank thee for thine honest care;
Which to requite, command me while I live.
This love of theirs myself have often seen,
Haply when they have judged me fast asleep,
And oftentimes have purposed to forbid
Sir Valentine her company and my court:
But fearing lest my jealous aim might err
And so unworthily disgrace the man,
A rashness that I ever yet have shunn'd,
I gave him gentle looks, thereby to find
That which thyself hast now disclosed to me.
And, that thou mayst perceive my fear of this,
Knowing that tender youth is soon suggested,
I nightly lodge her in an upper tower,
The key whereof myself have ever kept;
And thence she cannot be convey'd away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: Know, noble lord, they have devised a mean
How he her chamber-window will ascend
And with a corded ladder fetch her down;
For which the youthful lover now is gone
And this way comes he with it presently;
Where, if it please you, you may intercept him.
But, good my Lord, do it so cunningly
That my discovery be not aimed at;
For love of you, not hate unto my friend,
Hath made me publisher of this pretence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE
SPEECH.LINE: Upon mine honour, he shall never know
That I had any light from thee of this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: Adieu, my Lord; Sir Valentine is coming.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE
SPEECH.LINE: Sir Valentine, whither away so fast?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: Please it your grace, there is a messenger
That stays to bear my letters to my friends,
And I am going to deliver them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE
SPEECH.LINE: Be they of much import?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: The tenor of them doth but signify
My health and happy being at your court.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE
SPEECH.LINE: Nay then, no matter; stay with me awhile;
I am to break with thee of some affairs
That touch me near, wherein thou must be secret.
'Tis not unknown to thee that I have sought
To match my friend Sir Thurio to my daughter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: I know it well, my Lord; and, sure, the match
Were rich and honourable; besides, the gentleman
Is full of virtue, bounty, worth and qualities
Beseeming such a wife as your fair daughter:
Cannot your Grace win her to fancy him?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE
SPEECH.LINE: No, trust me; she is peevish, sullen, froward,
Proud, disobedient, stubborn, lacking duty,
Neither regarding that she is my child
Nor fearing me as if I were her father;
And, may I say to thee, this pride of hers,
Upon advice, hath drawn my love from her;
And, where I thought the remnant of mine age
Should have been cherish'd by her child-like duty,
I now am full resolved to take a wife
And turn her out to who will take her in:
Then let her beauty be her wedding-dower;
For me and my possessions she esteems not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: What would your Grace have me to do in this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE
SPEECH.LINE: There is a lady in Verona here
Whom I affect; but she is nice and coy
And nought esteems my aged eloquence:
Now therefore would I have thee to my tutor--
For long agone I have forgot to court;
Besides, the fashion of the time is changed--
How and which way I may bestow myself
To be regarded in her sun-bright eye.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: Win her with gifts, if she respect not words:
Dumb jewels often in their silent kind
More than quick words do move a woman's mind.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE
SPEECH.LINE: But she did scorn a present that I sent her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: A woman sometimes scorns what best contents her.
Send her another; never give her o'er;
For scorn at first makes after-love the more.
If she do frown, 'tis not in hate of you,
But rather to beget more love in you:
If she do chide, 'tis not to have you gone;
For why, the fools are mad, if left alone.
Take no repulse, whatever she doth say;
For 'get you gone,' she doth not mean 'away!'
Flatter and praise, commend, extol their graces;
Though ne'er so black, say they have angels' faces.
That man that hath a tongue, I say, is no man,
If with his tongue he cannot win a woman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE
SPEECH.LINE: But she I mean is promised by her friends
Unto a youthful gentleman of worth,
And kept severely from resort of men,
That no man hath access by day to her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: Why, then, I would resort to her by night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, but the doors be lock'd and keys kept safe,
That no man hath recourse to her by night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: What lets but one may enter at her window?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE
SPEECH.LINE: Her chamber is aloft, far from the ground,
And built so shelving that one cannot climb it
Without apparent hazard of his life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: Why then, a ladder quaintly made of cords,
To cast up, with a pair of anchoring hooks,
Would serve to scale another Hero's tower,
So bold Leander would adventure it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE
SPEECH.LINE: Now, as thou art a gentleman of blood,
Advise me where I may have such a ladder.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: When would you use it? pray, sir, tell me that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE
SPEECH.LINE: This very night; for Love is like a child,
That longs for every thing that he can come by.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: By seven o'clock I'll get you such a ladder.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE
SPEECH.LINE: But, hark thee; I will go to her alone:
How shall I best convey the ladder thither?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: It will be light, my lord, that you may bear it
Under a cloak that is of any length.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE
SPEECH.LINE: A cloak as long as thine will serve the turn?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, my good lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE
SPEECH.LINE: Then let me see thy cloak:
I'll get me one of such another length.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: Why, any cloak will serve the turn, my lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE
SPEECH.LINE: How shall I fashion me to wear a cloak?
I pray thee, let me feel thy cloak upon me.
What letter is this same? What's here? 'To Silvia'!
And here an engine fit for my proceeding.
I'll be so bold to break the seal for once.
'My thoughts do harbour with my Silvia nightly,
And slaves they are to me that send them flying:
O, could their master come and go as lightly,
Himself would lodge where senseless they are lying!
My herald thoughts in thy pure bosom rest them:
While I, their king, that hither them importune,
Do curse the grace that with such grace hath bless'd them,
Because myself do want my servants' fortune:
I curse myself, for they are sent by me,
That they should harbour where their lord would be.'
What's here?
'Silvia, this night I will enfranchise thee.'
'Tis so; and here's the ladder for the purpose.
Why, Phaeton,--for thou art Merops' son,--
Wilt thou aspire to guide the heavenly car
And with thy daring folly burn the world?
Wilt thou reach stars, because they shine on thee?
Go, base intruder! overweening slave!
Bestow thy fawning smiles on equal mates,
And think my patience, more than thy desert,
Is privilege for thy departure hence:
Thank me for this more than for all the favours
Which all too much I have bestow'd on thee.
But if thou linger in my territories
Longer than swiftest expedition
Will give thee time to leave our royal court,
By heaven! my wrath shall far exceed the love
I ever bore my daughter or thyself.
Be gone! I will not hear thy vain excuse;
But, as thou lovest thy life, make speed from hence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: And why not death rather than living torment?
To die is to be banish'd from myself;
And Silvia is myself: banish'd from her
Is self from self: a deadly banishment!
What light is light, if Silvia be not seen?
What joy is joy, if Silvia be not by?
Unless it be to think that she is by
And feed upon the shadow of perfection
Except I be by Silvia in the night,
There is no music in the nightingale;
Unless I look on Silvia in the day,
There is no day for me to look upon;
She is my essence, and I leave to be,
If I be not by her fair influence
Foster'd, illumined, cherish'd, kept alive.
I fly not death, to fly his deadly doom:
Tarry I here, I but attend on death:
But, fly I hence, I fly away from life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: Run, boy, run, run, and seek him out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAUNCE
SPEECH.LINE: Soho, soho!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: What seest thou?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAUNCE
SPEECH.LINE: Him we go to find: there's not a hair on's head
but 'tis a Valentine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: Valentine?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: No.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: Who then? his spirit?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: Neither.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: What then?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: Nothing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAUNCE
SPEECH.LINE: Can nothing speak? Master, shall I strike?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: Who wouldst thou strike?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAUNCE
SPEECH.LINE: Nothing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: Villain, forbear.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAUNCE
SPEECH.LINE: Why, sir, I'll strike nothing: I pray you,--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: Sirrah, I say, forbear. Friend Valentine, a word.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: My ears are stopt and cannot hear good news,
So much of bad already hath possess'd them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: Then in dumb silence will I bury mine,
For they are harsh, untuneable and bad.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: Is Silvia dead?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: No, Valentine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: No Valentine, indeed, for sacred Silvia.
Hath she forsworn me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: No, Valentine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: No Valentine, if Silvia have forsworn me.
What is your news?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAUNCE
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, there is a proclamation that you are vanished.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: That thou art banished--O, that's the news!--
From hence, from Silvia and from me thy friend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: O, I have fed upon this woe already,
And now excess of it will make me surfeit.
Doth Silvia know that I am banished?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, ay; and she hath offer'd to the doom--
Which, unreversed, stands in effectual force--
A sea of melting pearl, which some call tears:
Those at her father's churlish feet she tender'd;
With them, upon her knees, her humble self;
Wringing her hands, whose whiteness so became them
As if but now they waxed pale for woe:
But neither bended knees, pure hands held up,
Sad sighs, deep groans, nor silver-shedding tears,
Could penetrate her uncompassionate sire;
But Valentine, if he be ta'en, must die.
Besides, her intercession chafed him so,
When she for thy repeal was suppliant,
That to close prison he commanded her,
With many bitter threats of biding there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: No more; unless the next word that thou speak'st
Have some malignant power upon my life:
If so, I pray thee, breathe it in mine ear,
As ending anthem of my endless dolour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: Cease to lament for that thou canst not help,
And study help for that which thou lament'st.
Time is the nurse and breeder of all good.
Here if thou stay, thou canst not see thy love;
Besides, thy staying will abridge thy life.
Hope is a lover's staff; walk hence with that
And manage it against despairing thoughts.
Thy letters may be here, though thou art hence;
Which, being writ to me, shall be deliver'd
Even in the milk-white bosom of thy love.
The time now serves not to expostulate:
Come, I'll convey thee through the city-gate;
And, ere I part with thee, confer at large
Of all that may concern thy love-affairs.
As thou lovest Silvia, though not for thyself,
Regard thy danger, and along with me!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: I pray thee, Launce, an if thou seest my boy,
Bid him make haste and meet me at the North-gate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: Go, sirrah, find him out. Come, Valentine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALENTINE
SPEECH.LINE: O my dear Silvia! Hapless Valentine!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAUNCE
SPEECH.LINE: I am but a fool, look you; and yet I have the wit to
think my master is a kind of a knave: but that's
all one, if he be but one knave. He lives not now
that knows me to be in love; yet I am in love; but a
team of horse shall not pluck that from me; nor who
'tis I love; and yet 'tis a woman; but what woman, I
will not tell myself; and yet 'tis a milkmaid; yet
'tis not a maid, for she hath had gossips; yet 'tis
a maid, for she is her master's maid, and serves for
wages. She hath more qualities than a water-spaniel;
which is much in a bare Christian.
Here is the cate-log of her condition.
'Imprimis: She can fetch and carry.' Why, a horse
can do no more: nay, a horse cannot fetch, but only
carry; therefore is she better than a jade. 'Item:
She can milk;' look you, a sweet virtue in a maid
with clean hands.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: How now, Signior Launce! what news with your
mastership?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAUNCE
SPEECH.LINE: With my master's ship? why, it is at sea.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: Well, your old vice still; mistake the word. What
news, then, in your paper?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAUNCE
SPEECH.LINE: The blackest news that ever thou heardest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: Why, man, how black?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAUNCE
SPEECH.LINE: Why, as black as ink.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: Let me read them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAUNCE
SPEECH.LINE: Fie on thee, jolt-head! thou canst not read.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: Thou liest; I can.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAUNCE
SPEECH.LINE: I will try thee. Tell me this: who begot thee?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: Marry, the son of my grandfather.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAUNCE
SPEECH.LINE: O illiterate loiterer! it was the son of thy
grandmother: this proves that thou canst not read.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: Come, fool, come; try me in thy paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAUNCE
SPEECH.LINE: There; and St. Nicholas be thy speed!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: Reads 'Imprimis: She can milk.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAUNCE
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, that she can.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: 'Item: She brews good ale.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAUNCE
SPEECH.LINE: And thereof comes the proverb: 'Blessing of your
heart, you brew good ale.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: 'Item: She can sew.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAUNCE
SPEECH.LINE: That's as much as to say, Can she so?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: 'Item: She can knit.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAUNCE
SPEECH.LINE: What need a man care for a stock with a wench, when
she can knit him a stock?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: 'Item: She can wash and scour.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAUNCE
SPEECH.LINE: A special virtue: for then she need not be washed
and scoured.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: 'Item: She can spin.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAUNCE
SPEECH.LINE: Then may I set the world on wheels, when she can
spin for her living.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: 'Item: She hath many nameless virtues.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAUNCE
SPEECH.LINE: That's as much as to say, bastard virtues; that,
indeed, know not their fathers and therefore have no names.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: 'Here follow her vices.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAUNCE
SPEECH.LINE: Close at the heels of her virtues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: 'Item: She is not to be kissed fasting in respect
of her breath.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAUNCE
SPEECH.LINE: Well, that fault may be mended with a breakfast. Read on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: 'Item: She hath a sweet mouth.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAUNCE
SPEECH.LINE: That makes amends for her sour breath.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: 'Item: She doth talk in her sleep.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAUNCE
SPEECH.LINE: It's no matter for that, so she sleep not in her talk.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: 'Item: She is slow in words.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAUNCE
SPEECH.LINE: O villain, that set this down among her vices! To
be slow in words is a woman's only virtue: I pray
thee, out with't, and place it for her chief virtue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: 'Item: She is proud.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAUNCE
SPEECH.LINE: Out with that too; it was Eve's legacy, and cannot
be ta'en from her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: 'Item: She hath no teeth.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAUNCE
SPEECH.LINE: I care not for that neither, because I love crusts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: 'Item: She is curst.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAUNCE
SPEECH.LINE: Well, the best is, she hath no teeth to bite.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: 'Item: She will often praise her liquor.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAUNCE
SPEECH.LINE: If her liquor be good, she shall: if she will not, I
will; for good things should be praised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: 'Item: She is too liberal.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAUNCE
SPEECH.LINE: Of her tongue she cannot, for that's writ down she
is slow of; of her purse she shall not, for that
I'll keep shut: now, of another thing she may, and
that cannot I help. Well, proceed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: 'Item: She hath more hair than wit, and more faults
than hairs, and more wealth than faults.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAUNCE
SPEECH.LINE: Stop there; I'll have her: she was mine, and not
mine, twice or thrice in that last article.
Rehearse that once more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: 'Item: She hath more hair than wit,'--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAUNCE
SPEECH.LINE: More hair than wit? It may be; I'll prove it. The
cover of the salt hides the salt, and therefore it
is more than the salt; the hair that covers the wit
is more than the wit, for the greater hides the
less. What's next?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: 'And more faults than hairs,'--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAUNCE
SPEECH.LINE: That's monstrous: O, that that were out!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: 'And more wealth than faults.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAUNCE
SPEECH.LINE: Why, that word makes the faults gracious. Well,
I'll have her; and if it be a match, as nothing is
impossible,--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: What then?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAUNCE
SPEECH.LINE: Why, then will I tell thee--that thy master stays
for thee at the North-gate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: For me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAUNCE
SPEECH.LINE: For thee! ay, who art thou? he hath stayed for a
better man than thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: And must I go to him?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAUNCE
SPEECH.LINE: Thou must run to him, for thou hast stayed so long
that going will scarce serve the turn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPEED
SPEECH.LINE: Why didst not tell me sooner? pox of your love letters!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAUNCE
SPEECH.LINE: Now will he be swinged for reading my letter; an
unmannerly slave, that will thrust himself into
secrets! I'll after, to rejoice in the boy's correction.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE
SPEECH.LINE: Sir Thurio, fear not but that she will love you,
Now Valentine is banish'd from her sight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THURIO
SPEECH.LINE: Since his exile she hath despised me most,
Forsworn my company and rail'd at me,
That I am desperate of obtaining her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE
SPEECH.LINE: This weak impress of love is as a figure
Trenched in ice, which with an hour's heat
Dissolves to water and doth lose his form.
A little time will melt her frozen thoughts
And worthless Valentine shall be forgot.
How now, Sir Proteus! Is your countryman
According to our proclamation gone?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: Gone, my good lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE
SPEECH.LINE: My daughter takes his going grievously.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: A little time, my lord, will kill that grief.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE
SPEECH.LINE: So I believe; but Thurio thinks not so.
Proteus, the good conceit I hold of thee--
For thou hast shown some sign of good desert--
Makes me the better to confer with thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: Longer than I prove loyal to your grace
Let me not live to look upon your grace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE
SPEECH.LINE: Thou know'st how willingly I would effect
The match between Sir Thurio and my daughter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: I do, my lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE
SPEECH.LINE: And also, I think, thou art not ignorant
How she opposes her against my will

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: She did, my lord, when Valentine was here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, and perversely she persevers so.
What might we do to make the girl forget
The love of Valentine and love Sir Thurio?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROTEUS
SPEECH.LINE: The best way is to slander Valentine
With falsehood, cowardice and poor descent,
Three things that women highly hold in hate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE
